questions.text: Which of the following statements about the autonomic innervation of the gastrointestinal tract is correct?

choices.text: The vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to the entire length of the gut.
The pelvic splanchnic nerves supply sympathetic innervation to the hindgut.
The greater splanchnic nerves provide sympathetic innervation primarily to the midgut.
The parasympathetic supply to the hindgut originates from the sacral spinal cord.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The parasympathetic supply to the hindgut originates from the sacral spinal cord.

Explanation:
The parasympathetic supply to the hindgut originates from the sacral spinal cord, specifically from segments S2-S4. These fibers form the pelvic splanchnic nerves.

Foregut, midgut and hindgut- Innervation

 

Feature

Foregut

Midgut

Hindgut

Sympathetic (Preganglionic)

Preganglionic fibers arise from the thoracic spinal cord (T5–T9)- and form the greater splanchnic nerves, which travel to the celiac ganglia.

Preganglionic fibers arise from the thoracic spinal cord (T10–T11) - and form the lesser splanchnic nerves, which travel to the superior mesenteric ganglion.

Preganglionic fibers arise from the lumbar spinal cord (L1–L2) - and form the lumbar splanchnic nerves, which travel to the inferior mesenteric ganglion.

Sympathetic (Postganglionic)
  • Postganglionic fibers from the celiac ganglion supply the foregut organs.
  • These fibers follow branches of the celiac trunk to reach the target organs.
  • Postganglionic fibers from the superior mesenteric ganglion supply the midgut organs.
  • These fibers follow the superior mesenteric artery and its branches.
  • Postganglionic fibers from the inferior mesenteric ganglion supply the hindgut organs.
  • These fibers follow the inferior mesenteric artery and its branches.

Parasympathetic
  • Preganglionic parasympathetic fibers arise from the vagus nerve (CN X).
  • They pass through the celiac plexus and directly innervate the organs of the foregut.
  • Preganglionic parasympathetic fibers also arise from the vagus nerve (CN X).
  • They pass through the superior mesenteric plexus and innervate the midgut organs.
  • Preganglionic parasympathetic fibers arise from the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2–S4).
  • These fibers pass through the inferior hypogastric plexus and innervate the hindgut organs.

 

  • While the vagus nerve does provide parasympathetic innervation to a large portion of the gut, it does not supply the entire length.
  • It innervates the foregut and midgut, extending approximately to the proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon. (Option A)
  • The pelvic splanchnic nerves provide parasympathetic, not sympathetic, innervation to the hindgut. (Option B)
  • The greater splanchnic nerves primarily provide sympathetic innervation to the foregut structures, not the midgut. (Option C)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. He reports that the pain worsens after eating and is associated with nausea. On examination, there is epigastric tenderness, but no rebound or guarding. The patient's past medical history is significant for chronic pancreatitis. You suspect autonomic involvement in his pain pattern. Which of the following nerves is most likely involved in transmitting the visceral pain signals from the pancreas?

choices.text: Greater splanchnic nerve
Lesser splanchnic nerve
Pelvic splanchnic nerve
Vagus nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Greater splanchnic nerve

 

Explanation:

Epigastric pain radiating to the back in case of chronic pancreatitis is due to autonomic innervation via the greater splanchnic nerve.

 

Sympathetic Innervation:

The nerve supply of the abdomen is primarily through the sympathetic and parasympathetic systems, with the sympathetic innervation arising from the thoracic sympathetic chain.

 

  • The sympathetic fibers that supply the abdomen primarily come from the lower thoracic splanchnic nerves, which are part of the thoracic sympathetic trunk.
  • These nerves include the greater, lesser, and least splanchnic nerves, which originate from the T5 to T12 vertebral levels.

These nerves carry presynaptic sympathetic fibers that travel through the sympathetic trunk without synapsing and enter the abdominopelvic splanchnic nerves.

  • The greater splanchnic nerve (T5–T9) synapses in the celiac ganglion, providing sympathetic innervation to foregut derivatives, including the stomach, liver, pancreas, and parts of the small intestine.
    • Chronic pancreatitis can cause epigastric pain, often referred to the back due to autonomic innervation via the greater splanchnic nerve. (Option A)
  • The lesser splanchnic nerve (T10–T11) synapses in the superior mesenteric ganglion, innervating the midgut derivatives, including the small intestine and parts of the colon. (Option B)
  • The least splanchnic nerve (T12) innervates the kidneys via the aorticorenal ganglion.

 

After synapsing in the prevertebral ganglia (like the celiac, superior mesenteric, and aorticorenal ganglia), the postsynaptic fibers follow the arterial branches in peri-arterial plexuses to their target organs.

  • Sympathetic stimulation in the abdomen primarily causes vasoconstriction and inhibits peristalsis.
  • This sympathetic supply is important for regulating blood flow and slowing down gastrointestinal activity, particularly during stress responses (fight or flight).

 

Pelvic splanchnic nerve (Option C): Involved in parasympathetic supply to the hindgut, not the foregut.

  • Pain from the pancreas would not be transmitted via this nerve.

 

Vagus nerve (Option D): Primarily parasympathetic, focusing on motility and secretions.

  • It does not carry the sympathetic visceral pain signals from the pancreas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with dull, poorly localized abdominal pain that began 12 hours ago. Over time, the pain becomes sharper and more localized in the right lower quadrant. The patient also reports nausea and loss of appetite. On physical examination, tenderness is noted at McBurney's point. Which of the following best explains the initial presentation of the patient's pain?

choices.text: Irritation of the peritoneum
Stimulation of visceral afferent fibers accompanying sympathetic nerves
Direct irritation of somatic nerves in the abdominal wall
Referred pain via the phrenic nerve (C3-C5)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stimulation of visceral afferent fibers accompanying sympathetic nerves

 

Explanation:

Referred pain occurs when visceral afferent fibers transmit pain signals to the spinal cord, which misinterprets these signals as originating from a somatic region innervated by the same spinal segment (same dermatome).

 

  • Initially, the pain in appendicitis is referred to the periumbilical region due to irritation of visceral afferent fibers.
  • These fibers travel with the sympathetic nerves (thoracolumbar flow), which innervate the small intestine.
  • As the inflammation progresses and the parietal peritoneum becomes involved, the pain localizes to the right lower quadrant.
  • Unlike visceral pain, pain from structures like the parietal peritoneum is more localized and sharp.
  • This type of pain is mediated by somatic nerves, which can pinpoint the exact area of irritation.

 

Referred pain and associated dermatomes:

Region

Dermatome

Shoulder tip

C4

Nipples

T4

Epigastrium (Foregut pain)

T7

Periumbilical (Umbilical pain)

T10

Suprapubic region (Inguinal region)

L1

Little toe

S1

The lower limb will begin in L1 and S1 region

 

Irritation of the peritoneum (Option A): This explains the late phase of appendicitis when the pain becomes sharp and localized due to somatic innervation of the parietal peritoneum.

  • However, it does not account for the initial referred pain.

Direct irritation of somatic nerves in the abdominal wall (Option C): Somatic nerves cause sharp, well-localized pain, as seen in later-stage appendicitis, but they do not explain the initial vague, dull pain.

 

Referred pain via the phrenic nerve (C3-C5) (Option D): The phrenic nerve innervates the diaphragm and causes referred pain to the shoulder (e.g., from diaphragmatic irritation).

  • It is unrelated to appendicitis or abdominal pain.

questions.text: At which vertebral level does the abdominal aorta typically bifurcate into the common iliac arteries?

choices.text: L2
L4
L5

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) L4

Explanation:
The abdominal aorta typically bifurcates into the common iliac arteries at the level of the L4 vertebra.

  • This bifurcation point is an important anatomical landmark in the abdomen.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with severe abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. CT angiography reveals thrombosis of a major vein draining the distal transverse colon, descending colon, and sigmoid colon. Which of the following veins is most likely to be affected in this patient's condition?

choices.text: Hepatic portal vein
Superior mesenteric vein
Inferior mesenteric vein
Celiac vein

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inferior mesenteric vein

Explanation:
The patient's symptoms and the affected area (distal transverse colon, descending colon, and sigmoid colon) indicate an issue with the hindgut and its blood supply.

  • Hindgut is drained by inferior mesenteric vein.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the innervation and vascular supply of the uterus and vagina is correct?

choices.text: The parasympathetic supply to the entire uterus and vagina comes from the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4)
The uterine artery is a branch of the external iliac artery
The vaginal venous plexus drains primarily into the internal pudendal vein
The superior part of the vagina receives its arterial supply from the vaginal artery, while the inferior part is supplied by branches of the internal pudendal artery

questions.solution:
orrect Answer: D) The superior part of the vagina receives its arterial supply from the vaginal artery, while the inferior part is supplied by branches of the internal pudendal artery

Explanation:
The superior part of the vagina receives its arterial supply from the vaginal artery, while branches of the internal pudendal artery supply the inferior part.

  • The uterine artery is a branch of the internal iliac artery, not the external iliac artery. (Option B)
  • The vaginal venous plexus drains primarily into the internal iliac veins, not the internal pudendal vein. (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pre-aortic and para-aortic lymph nodes is correct?

choices.text: Pre-aortic nodes primarily drain lymph from the lower limbs
Para-aortic nodes are located posterior to the abdominal aorta
Coeliac nodes are a subset of pre-aortic nodes
Lateral aortic nodes drain lymph from the stomach and pancreas

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Coeliac nodes are a subset of pre-aortic nodes

Explanation:
Coeliac nodes are a constituent of the pre-aortic group of lymph nodes.

  • Pre-aortic nodes can be subdivided into coeliac, superior mesenteric and inferior mesenteric nodes.

Pre-aortic and para-aortic lymph nodes

Lymph Node Group

Location

Primary Drainage

Subgroups

Pre-aortic nodes

Anterior to the abdominal aorta

Gastrointestinal viscera including pancreas, liver, spleen

Coeliac, superior mesenteric, inferior mesenteric nodes

Para-aortic nodes (Lateral aortic)

On either side of the abdominal aorta

Deep layers of body wall, retroperitoneal pelvic viscera, gonads (testes and ovaries)

Left and right lumbar (of the kidney), aortocaval, retrocaval, precaval groups
  • Pre-aortic nodes primarily drain lymph from gastrointestinal viscera, not the lower limbs. (Option A)
  • Para-aortic nodes (also called lateral aortic nodes) are located on either side of the abdominal aorta, not posterior to it. (Option B)
  • Lateral aortic nodes (para-aortic) primarily drain lymph from the deep layers of the body wall, retroperitoneal pelvic viscera, and gonads.(Option D).
    • The stomach and pancreas are primarily drained by pre-aortic nodes (specifically coeliac and superior mesenteric nodes).

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents with pain in his right lower quadrant. Imaging reveals no abnormalities in the appendix, yet the patient experiences referred pain that radiates to the periumbilical region. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?

choices.text: Convergence of somatic and visceral afferent fibers in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord
Specific nerve injury affecting the parietal peritoneum
Direct stimulation of visceral pain fibers in the appendix
Local irritation of the somatic sensory nerves in the abdominal wall

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Convergence of somatic and visceral afferent fibers in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord

 

Explanation:

The Convergence Projection Hypothesis explains how visceral pain is often misinterpreted as somatic pain.

  • Visceral organs are innervated by visceral afferent fibers, which enter the spinal cord at the same segmental level as somatic afferents.
  • When these visceral fibers converge with somatic fibers in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord, the brain interprets the signal as originating from the somatic region, leading to referred pain.
  • In the case of appendicitis, visceral afferents from the appendix converge with somatic afferents from the T10 dermatome, resulting in referred pain around the umbilicus.

Specific nerve injury affecting the parietal peritoneum (Option B): While irritation of the parietal peritoneum can cause sharp, localized pain, this does not explain referred pain to a distant somatic area.

 

Direct stimulation of visceral pain fibers in the appendix (Option C) would result in poorly localized, dull, and cramping pain, typically felt in the midline.

 

Local irritation of the somatic sensory nerves in the abdominal wall (Option D): Irritation of somatic sensory nerves would lead to localized pain directly at the site of irritation, not referred pain.
